Text 1: We Berliners should take the chance and become pioneers in waste separation! Yes, it's annoying and cumbersome to separate your rubbish properly all the time. Text 5: The universities in Germany should not under any circumstances charge tuition fees. This would impede or prevent access to those who are financially weaker. And funding-wise it ought to be considered how costs incurred by students from other (federal) states can be reimbursed.
Text 6: There should be a higher fine for dog dirt on the pavement. Dog dirt is disgusting and a hygiene problem. Also children, adults and other animals aren't allowed to leave droppings on the pavement. If you dispose of the waste then and there yourself, no fine is necessary.
Text 7: I find the peripheral housing development at Tempelhofer Feld right for urban planning reasons, as the area is right in the middle of the city (capital). The size of the field allows for both housing and generous open space.
Text 8: Tuition fees should not generally be charged by universities. Universities are for all citizens, independent of their finances. Education and training are fundamental rights which the state, the society must provide. If a university lacks the funds, sponsors must be found. Unfortunately this can lead to disagreeable dependencies in some cases.
Text 9: The morning-after pill ought to be available over-the-counter in pharmacies. Even with state-of-the-art contraceptives there can be mistakes and problems and an unwanted pregnancy can place a significant strain on both the parents and the child for the rest of their lives. Some dog owners assume that paying a dog licence fee covers the removal of such waste, but according to this logic one could hardly make the taxpayer accountable for almost any offense.

The unregulated work of the secret services, however, carries the danger of misuse of their authority.
Text 12: The morning-after pill should only be prescribed after counselling by a physician or pharmacist. The morning-after pill has a number of side effects. Text 13: Universities should not charge tuition fees in Germany. Every German citizen has a right to education. Text 14: Germany's aging society is undergoing demographic change, and the age of those who are physically and mentally fit is increasing steadily. Raising the relative retirement age on the basis of the physical fitness of the average citizen is fair.
Text 15: Due to the increase in opening hours on Sundays and holidays there is a rise in employment. On top of that, private and family life suffers massively because of this reduction and shifting in designated off-times. And it’s only the large companies that can afford the additional personnel expenditure. For these reasons supermarkets and shopping centres should not be allowed to be open for business on arbitrary Sundays and holidays.

If however one could find a compromise between green space and housing, then Tempelhofer Feld should definitely be made available for residential construction.

Also, one isn't taking responsibility for society if one gives up one's experienced, healthy and highly qualified capabilities earlier than necessary for private/personal reasons.

Some worry about careless use of such measures, but this problem should rather be addressed with comprehensive prior education. The morning-after pill ought to be available over-the-counter in pharmacies.
Text 10: There should be much higher fines for dog dirt left on pavements. Stepping in dog dirt is gross and absolutely ruins your day due to the dirt, the stench and the often considerable effort to get rid of it. Besides, the fines for public urination by a human are higher than for leaving behind dog dirt on the pavement, which is disproportionate. Some dog owners assume that paying a dog licence fee covers the removal of such waste, but according to this logic one could hardly make the taxpayer accountable for almost any offense.
Text 11: Intelligence services must be regulated in the framework of parliamentary oversight committees. Intelligence services apparently enjoy indiscriminate liberties. The unregulated work of the secret services, however, carries the danger of misuse of their authority.
Text 12: The morning-after pill should only be prescribed after counselling by a physician or pharmacist. The morning-after pill has a number of side effects. However these are clearly stated on the package insert, and a request for an early termination of a pregnancy is the right of every woman.
Text 13: Universities should not charge tuition fees in Germany. Every German citizen has a right to education. Quality at universities has its price, which is why students also ought to be involved in this cost factor. But education must not be a question of money in a wealthy society such as Germany.
Text 14: Germany's aging society is undergoing demographic change, and the age of those who are physically and mentally fit is increasing steadily. Thus social security and pension costs are increasing. Yet no one should be required to work for more than 40 years. Raising the relative retirement age on the basis of the physical fitness of the average citizen is fair.
Text 15: Due to the increase in opening hours on Sundays and holidays there is a rise in employment. However it's mainly temps (that is, students, pupils etc.) who are employed, so this has hardly any effect on the level of full-time employment and the number of unemployed. On top of that, private and family life suffers massively because of this reduction and shifting in designated off-times. And it’s only the large companies that can afford the additional personnel expenditure. For these reasons supermarkets and shopping centres should not be allowed to be open for business on arbitrary Sundays and holidays.
Text 16: For years there has been a housing shortage in Berlin, so that using Tempelhofer Feld, which offers a lot of open space and is currently hardly developed, as living space is a sensible idea. Admittedly the fields have currently become an attractive leisure park with sporting areas for many visitors and Berliners, especially in spring and summer. If however one could find a compromise between green space and housing, then Tempelhofer Feld should definitely be made available for residential construction.
Text 17: EU should intervene right away. A violation of international law should be more than enough to consider a reaction! Text 18: Retirement at 63, that's something everyone who has toiled away (nonstop) up to this point surely deserves. Especially now, as there is a lack of skilled labour, it's irresponsible for the economy and prosperity to retire at 63.
Text 19: Opening on Sundays and holidays would help both customers and shops. Owner-run shops may potentially be overwhelmed by additional work times on Sundays and holidays, then again supermarkets and large shopping centres dominate the market today already. Thus smaller shops could benefit from the additional freedom, as customers are on average more laid-back on Sunday.
Text 20: After the new BER Airport has been commissioned, Tegel should definitely be closed. I think Berlin with its two inner-city airports was lucky not having to experience an airplane catastrophe for decades. For safety reasons alone I find continued operation wrong. Inner-city areas will be upgraded economically due to these factors (housing health and employment).

Yet no one should be required to work for more than 40 years.

However it's mainly temps (that is, students, pupils etc.) who are employed, so this has hardly any effect on the level of full-time employment and the number of unemployed. And it’s only the large companies that can afford the additional personnel expenditure. For these reasons supermarkets and shopping centres should not be allowed to be open for business on arbitrary Sundays and holidays.
